It belongs to the family Hymenophyllaceae and is characterized by its delicate, creeping growth habit. The plant produces small, clustered sporangia on the underside of its leaves, which are typically covered with a thin, membranous layer. It thrives in humid, shaded environments, often found on rock surfaces or in dense forest undergrowth. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
